comment: I was replacing an older modem separate router setup max speed measured was 150Mbps at 5G and 72Mbps at 2.4 G.We have Time Warner / Spectrum service.  I made the connections according to the instructions for setup for the new Arris Surfboard by Ethernet cable but I wasn't able to connect to the internet.  I called tech support for Arris and was on hold for 75 minutes.  They told me that I have to contact my service ( TW / Spec ) and activate the modem first, then call them for help.  The instructions that came with the modem did not say that in the setup instructions at all.  Even the guy on the phone said " Yeah, we missed that part"  Called TW / Spect next on hold again....you know how that feels...recorded message..Your call is important to us, please stay on the line....etc...finally got thru and they sent the activate signal for the new Arris to workThat was the bad part......BOOOOO....cost Arris a starGood part now....Setup using the ethernet cable connection to a laptop Win 7 got into the menu using 192.168.0.1default login is  admin  PW  password and was able to continue the setup from there for 2.4 and 5 G home networksI down loaded an app  Wifi Analytics from Netgear ( free) and was able to measure Wireless signal strength all over the house and patio.  MUCH MUCH better with before and after tests  Example..  5G on patio was 6 Mbps before, now 117Mbps with Arris.  All signals throughout the house much better and stronger, connections speeds at 5G much better depending on the room ( distance ) and walls in the way speeds are 390 Mbps to 865 Mbps nowThe Netgear app has a house measure feature with allows you to go room to room and measure signals and speeds so you can map your house and place the Arris in the best spot for results.Hint for setup...download to your cell or tablet an app that lets you measure signals and speed for Wifi, this will really help you and measure your signals before you make a change so you know how much improvement you get...or not...Next...after you connect your Arris Surfboard to your service provider call them and have them send the activate signal so you can get started on the rest of the setup.  After setup is finished and working...go back and remeasure all the signals in the same spot as before you started...so you can see the difference

Did speedtest's using the same server point on both 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz before swapping from the Xfinity provided unit to this new Arris and the results were nearly identical. About 179Mbps download and 11.4Mbps upload on 5Ghz for both on Blast+ 150Mbps service. With the 2.4Ghz though... with 3 tests of 2.4Ghz on the stock unit I hit about 58.2Mbps download and 10.8Mbps upload each time, and on the Arris I hit 57 download the first test and the next two were about 110!  Could be a fluke with variables on the test server etc, but the 2.4Ghz seems to be better on the Arris! Love that this is a matte finish plastic all around though compared to the Xfinity. So no fingerprints and less noticeable dust!CONS: Only issue I've noticed after a couple weeks of use is that the downward antenna range on this is near non existent compared to the stock xfinity modem.  I live in a 1050 sqft dublex style 2 story and with the Arris in the top left room (2nd floor) I now have only 1 bar/no wifi in the kitchen (bottom right, 1st floor).  I have not tried the opposite setup with the Arris on the ground floor to see if the upward antenna range is better, but If range is important for you, or you have a 2 story I suggest trying this on the ground floor or going with a different unit.UPDATE: In a new 660sqft ground level apt. im losing signal in the next room only 10 steps down the hall from the bedroom.  Also, weaker signal just through one wall into my living room. Definitely not suitable for a large house. I hope they fix this with FW in the future.  When youre close its amazing, but walk away and you can watch the signal start dropping bars-also these LED's are BRIGHT! I put black paper tape over the front LEDs which worked well for the indicators, but the open vent holes on the top of the unit allow for a lot of blue light spill, basically a blue tennis racket like pattern projected on your wall. So be prepared to have to find some entertainment center cabinet to cover this with etc.

Have had this for several months so I figured it was a good enough time to use it and review it.Set up as usual was easy.Plug it in and call the internet company, Cox in my case.After a few minutes of telling them some information about the unit and waiting for blinking lights, internet was back on!Our last modem/router was also “ac” but wasn’t nearly as fast or could handle as many devices.We have a smart tv, 2 iPhones, 2 iPads, a MacBook Pro, plus devices from family and friends that come over.Not a ton of devices, but the upgrade definitely helped.Before if someone was watching Netflix, the internet would slow to a crawl for everyone else.Not anymore!A nice bonus was our download speed is higher than the rated average we pay for.The USB plus is amazing as well, I have my hard drive plugged in and can access information from it on our devices and even smart tv.Still trying to figure out port forwarding and all that so I can access it away from home, maybe some day...

My first customer-owned model was a Netgear - but, it failed, and so my search for a new modem/router combo began. I settled on this specific model for several reasons: First and foremost, it had the best customer ratings. Second, it offered better Wi-Fi coverage. Third, it is 24x8, meaning, this will still work if I upgrade to gigabit internet in the future. All told, the WiFi signal is acceptable - not quite as good as the Netgear; but, it works reliably, whereas the Netgear did not.As far as the web interface, I found the router settings easy to work with (but I'm quite seasoned with this stuff). It does run a little slow at times; but, no complaints. It is easy to navigate through, and offers several customization features to satisfy all users, beginners to experts.

Forget about ARRIS tech suppport. They told me to go on Web Manager.  I did.  I can't access my modem settings.  They told me to do a factory reset.  I did that.  I try again.  I still can't log into Web Manager or McAfee SHI.  I went on ARRIS chat again and they tell me to do another factory reset, power cycle my modem, and power cycle my computer.  After all of the steps followed, I still cannot go on Web Manager or McAfee SHI.  If you want a modem that has similar parental control capabilities as a modem leased through a cable company look at a different brand besides ARRIS such as Net Gear.

The Arris SURFboard SBG7400AC2 combo modem/router unit is a very solid product. After over 1 month of use in our 2 story 1800 square foot home, it has worked flawlessly. Absolutely no issues.I purchased this product to replace a Netgear C6220 combo unit that I had for 2 years and I was never too happy with it's (under) performance.Set up for the Arris SURFboard SBG7400AC2 unit was extremely easy with our comcast internet. I simply hooked up our laptop to it using the provided Ethernet cable, followed the simple instructions and I was online in less than 10 minutes. No phone call to internet provider was needed.Unlike our previous Netgear unit, The Arris SURFboard SBG7400AC2 has been able to handle everything we throw at it. We have a smart home with a lot of devices including Amazon Alexa devices in just about every room and I have to say everything works perfectly.I pay for 60 mbps internet and I was lucky to get 10 to 20 mbps wifi with our old netgear unit. This Arris unit gives me 60 to 70 mbps on wifi!! HUGE difference in overall performance!Finally, It's so nice not to think about our internet anymore, or having to reboot our router every few days. This Arris unit simply WORKS! I would highly recommend it.Also, if you're still renting a modem from your internet provider, you are throwing away your money! I am a network engineer. So, my life is routing. This router is FAST, but theoretical speed is nothing if the router cannot handle it. After all, your network is only as fast as the slowest device. So, having a high amount of download bandwidth from your ISP is useless if your equipment cannot support it (bandwidth vs throughput). This device is capable of 1Gbps, and most of us only have an internet speed of < 100Mbps. This is from the ISP to the device. Once inside your home, the wifi supports speeds of 2340 Mbps or 2Gbps. and the ethernet port of 1Gbps. Basically, it is overkill. That, however, means little if you are connecting more devices than you have available download channels. There are 24 download and 8 upload. We currently have 3 wifi TVs, 4 PCs, 2 tablets, and 4 phones in my house, and we have no issues with buffering on my 100Mbps connection from Xfinity.The wifi route uses 802.11ac2 which provides the faster speeds I mentioned before but also uses beamforming. That means the signal focuses on connected devices with a stronger signal instead of just pushing equal strength into unused areas of your home. AC also supports both 2.4GHz and 5Ghz. 2.4 has a lower wave and travels further, at the expense of some speed, and 5 has a high wave with faster speed, at the expense of distance. 802.11ac2 will work the same on any router you get (in theory).If I had to nit-pick something, it would be the web interface. It can be slow at times, but you really only need to use it on the initial setup.
